newsitem.title: CHINA: China to boost control on personal tax collection.
newsitem.headline: China to boost control on personal tax collection.

text.p: Chinese tax authorities have issued a directive outlining tougher rules on collection and supervision of personal tax, the Shanghai Securities said on Thursday.
A circular from the State Administration of Taxation said government departments should coordinate and cooperate in the collection and supervision of personal tax.
Tax authorities should focus particularly on high-income earners, and major cases of tax evasion should be dealt with seriously according to the law, it said.
Individual tax collection and supervision institutions should be set up, it said without gaving further details.
Tax officials have said many people in China are failing to pay their income taxs due to lack of awareness, tax officials have said.

China introduced its first individual income tax law in 1980 and a 1994 revision outlines graduated tax rates of five percent to 45 percent, with the minimum taxable income set at 800 yuan a month and incomes of more than 100,000 yuan a month falling into the highest tax bracket.
China's personal income tax revenue rose by 43.7 percent to 5.409 billion yuan ($651.7 million) in the first quarter of 1997 compared with the year-ago period, the official newspaper said.
